required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of a Low Glycemic Load Diet on Hormonal Markers Associated With Acne
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Low Glycemic Load Diet on Hormonal Markers Associated With Acne

brief_summary.textblock: This randomized controlled trial will examine changes in some hormonal markers associated with acne among adults with moderate/severe acne randomized to a low glycemic index and glycemic load diet or usual eating plan for two weeks.

detailed_description.textblock: The objectives of this randomized controlled trial are to investigate the impact of a low glycemic index/load eating plan on endocrine aspects of acne. Specifically, this study will examine changes in blood biochemical markers of acne among adults with acne following a modified carbohydrate (low glycemic index/load) eating plan or their usual eating plan for two weeks. An external sponsor, Nutrisystem®, will provide some low glycemic index/load foods to the study participants randomized to the intervention group for two weeks. Study outcomes include changes in glucose, insulin, insulin resistance, insulin-like growth factor-1, and insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 concentrations.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline blood glucose concentrations after two weeks.
primary_outcome.description: A trained clinician will use venipuncture to draw approximately 30 mL of blood to measure glucose concentrations

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline insulin concentrations after two weeks.
primary_outcome.description: A trained clinician will use venipuncture to draw approximately 30 mL of blood to measure insulin concentrations

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline Insulin-like growth factor-1 concentrations after two weeks.
primary_outcome.description: A trained clinician will use venipuncture to draw approximately 30 mL of blood to measure insulin-like growth factor-1 concentrations

primary_outcome.measure: Insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 in mg/L
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 concentrations after two weeks.
primary_outcome.description: A trained clinician will use venipuncture to draw approximately 30 mL of blood to measure insulin-like growth factor binding protein-3 concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in Acne specific quality of life among participants following a low glycemic load diet or their usual diet for two weeks.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in baseline quality of life after two weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Acne specific quality of life will be measured using a validated questionnaire. Acne specific quality of life measured the effect of acne on the participants quality of life.

other_outcome.measure: Changes in nutrition self efficacy among participants following a low glycemic load diet or their usual diet for two weeks
other_outcome.time_frame: Change in nutrition self-efficacy after two-weeks.
other_outcome.description: Nutrition self-efficacy, or the ability to make diet changes, will be measured using a validated questionnaire.

arm_group.description: Participants received a diet education to follow a low glycemic load diet and received some low glycemic load staple foods.
Participants received a diet education to continue with their usual diet.

intervention.description: Participants received a diet education on a low glycemic load diet.
Participants received a diet education to continue with their usual eating plan.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index (BMI) ≥18.5 or <30.0 kg/m2
- History of moderate or severe facial acne for at least 6 months
- Able to read and speak the English language
Exclusion Criteria:
- > 10% weight change within the last 6 months
- Taking medications known to alter blood glucose or insulin concentrations
- Medical history of polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 1 diabetes, type 2 diabetes, or pre diabetes
- Low carbohydrate (<45% of total energy from carbohydrate), glycemic index, or glycemic load diet
- Female participants that are pregnant or lactating or were pregnant or lactating within the last year
- Current use of a pacemaker or other battery operated implant
- Facial hair that would make it difficult for a health care provider to assess facial acne.

reference.citation: Burris J, Rietkerk W, Woolf K. Acne: the role of medical nutrition therapy. J Acad Nutr Diet. 2013 Mar;113(3):416-30. doi: 10.1016/j.jand.2012.11.016. Review.
